column3: A middle-aged man presents with new-onset seizures and a calcified frontal lobe mass.
column4: Here we see fried egg cells

column3: A woman presents with worsening headaches and a rapidly enlarging ring-enhancing brain lesion.
column4: Here we see necrosis and pseudopallisading

column3: A child presents with gait instability and a midline cerebellar mass causing obstructive hydrocephalus.
column4: Here we see small round cells with high mitotic activity

column3: A school-aged child presents with nausea, vomiting, and a tumor arising from the floor of the fourth ventricle.
A person presents with seizures and an extra-axial mass.
column4: Here we see whorls of cells

column3: An older man presents with gradually progressive difficulty remembering recent events.
An older woman presents with memory problems that are interfering with her medications and household finances.
column4: Here we see neuritic plaques and tau tangles.

column3: A middle-aged man presents with a tremor and constipation.
A woman presents with movement disorder
A man presents with rapidly progressive memory loss and behavioral changes.
